description: From Latin prōstitūtus, past participle of prōstituō, from prō̆ (“for, before”) +‎ statuō (“to set up, to erect”).

adjectives.description: prostitute (comparative more prostitute, superlative most prostitute)

entries.meaning: (obsolete) Debased, corrupt; seeking personal gain by dishonourable means. [16th–19th c.]
examples: [H]e speaks a languages that merits not reply, and which can only excite contempt for his prostitute principles, or pity for his ignorance.

entries.meaning: Taking part in promiscuous sexual activity, licentious; (later, chiefly as attributive use of noun) that is a prostitute. [from 16th c.]
examples: They rightly say that attacks against prostitute women are common and that it's only when five are murdered in one place that it starts to provoke debate.
As a matter of ease, exposed and prostitute to every Mother-wit, and to be attained without any great care or study.

definitionGroups.group: Any person (especially a woman) who has sexual intercourse or engages in other sexual activity for payment, especially as a means of livelihood. [from 18th c.]

entries.meaning: A woman who has sexual intercourse or engages in other sexual activity for payment, especially as a means of livelihood. [from 17th c.]
examples: Unfortunately, there is to my knowledge no visual evidence for the dress of the Roman prostitute, but the literary sources present us with a range of prostitute clothing (from rich accoutrements all the way down to nothing),  […]

entries.meaning: A person who does, or offers to do, a demeaning or dishonourable activity for money or personal gain; someone who acts in a dishonourable way for personal advantage. [from 17th c.]

verbs.description: prostitute (third-person singular simple present prostitutes, present participle prostituting, simple past and past participle prostituted)

entries.meaning: (transitive, reflexive) To offer (oneself or someone else) for sexual activity in exchange for money. [from 16th c.]
(transitive, derogatory) To sacrifice (oneself, one's talents etc.) in return for profit or other advantage; to exploit for base purposes.
